description:
Bhargavaea changchunensis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Changchun, China. It belongs to the Bhargavaea genus, which is a member of the Firmicutes phylum.

The cells of B. changchunensis are Gram-positive, spore-forming, and rod-shaped. They are capable of growing under both aerobic and anaerobic conditions, with an optimal growth temperature around 30-37Â°C.

Phylogenetic analysis based on 16S rRNA gene sequencing has shown that B. changchunensis is most closely related to other Bhargavaea species, sharing approximately 97% sequence similarity. This suggests that it represents a distinct species within the Bhargavaea genus.

Not much is known about the specific metabolic capabilities or ecological roles of B. changchunensis, as it is a relatively newly described species. Further research would be needed to elucidate its physiological characteristics and potential applications.
